required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Brain Imaging, Nutrition, and Cognition in Breast Cancer Survivors
clinical_study.official_title: How Integrity of the Connectome and Nutritional Status Change Brain Function in Breast Cancer Patients Undergoing Chemotherapy

brief_summary.textblock: Up to 78% of women diagnosed with breast cancer experience impairments in their cognitive function (e.g., frequent forgetfulness, slow processing speeds, and difficulties in concentration, multitasking and/or word retrieval) in the course of cancer treatment. These cognitive impairments (CI) have negative effects on patients' social relationships, overall life satisfaction, and treatment adherence. Dietary intake may be an important factor in mitigating risk of CI that breast cancer patients experience. Several studies have suggested that dietary intake of specific nutrients and foods (e.g., carotenoids, B-vitamin, and omega-3 fatty acids rich foods) can be helpful to decrease the severity of cancer-related cognitive impairment (CRCI). High-quality dietary patterns can be also helpful to protect white matter volume and its integrity; damage to and changes in white matter contributes to CRCI. However, despite the high incidence of CRCI in breast cancer patients, very little is known about etiology of CRCI. Thus, the purpose of this observational study with cross-sectional design is to examine the relationships of diet with brain structural and functional outcomes of breast cancer patients. The study will aim to enroll 30 female postmenopausal breast cancer survivors (age 45-65) who have recently completed chemotherapy treatment within 3-6 months from study enrollment. Participants will complete study questionnaires online, and will have an in-person study visit to complete a functional magnetic resonance imagine (MRI) scan, cognitive testing, and blood sample collection via fingerstick and venous blood draw. We expect our study will advance the field's understanding and ability to early assess, manage, and prevent CRCI.

primary_outcome.measure: Evaluate feasibility through recruitment and retention
primary_outcome.description: Retention is determined by numbers of participants who drop out from the study versus compared to those who complete the study.

secondary_outcome.description: Assess brain connectivity from MRI images
Assess diet quality measures from an electronic food frequency questionnaire

secondary_outcome.measure: Assessment of cognition using the Hopkins Verbal Learning Test
secondary_outcome.description: Assess cognition by using the Hopkins Verbal Learning Test (HVLT), a brief cognitive test of episodic memory and verbal learning.

secondary_outcome.measure: Assessment of cognition using the WAIS-IV Digit Span
secondary_outcome.description: Assess cognition by using the Wechsler Adult Intelligence Scale (WAIS)-IV Digit Span, a cognitive test of attention and working memory.

secondary_outcome.measure: Assessment of cognition using the Oral Trail Making Test
secondary_outcome.description: Assess cognition by using the Oral Trail Making Test (TMT), a brief cognitive test of executive function and attention.

secondary_outcome.measure: Assessment of cognition using the COWA Test
secondary_outcome.description: Assess cognition by using the Controlled Oral Word Association (COWA) Test, a brief cognitive test of oral fluency and executive function.

secondary_outcome.measure: Assessment of cognition using the Boston Naming Test
secondary_outcome.description: Assess cognition by using the Boston Naming Test Short Form, a brief test of language.

secondary_outcome.measure: Assessment of presence of CRCI symptoms
secondary_outcome.description: Assess presence of cancer-related cognitive impairment (CRCI) symptoms using the Neuro-QoL Cognitive Function Test, a self-report measurement of cognitive function.

biospec_descr.textblock: Whole blood dried blood spots; whole blood venous blood samples

study_pop.textblock: Breast cancer survivors from the Central Ohio area, including those who were seen at The Ohio State University Wexner Medical Center James Cancer Hospital for cancer treatment.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Stage I-III breast cancer diagnosis
- Between 3-6 months post-treatment with adjuvant anthracycline or taxane-based chemotherapy
- Postmenopausal (at least 12 months without menses; OR on ovarian suppression medication; OR status post oophorectomy)
- English speaking
Exclusion Criteria:
- Women who have permanent ferromagnetic metal in the body, a pacemaker, or have severe claustrophobia
- Women who are pregnant or breastfeeding
- Diagnosis of alcohol or substance use disorders, or any psychoactive medication use within the past 4 months
- Current diagnosis of dementia, psychosis or major depressive disorders
- Concurrent other malignancy or metastatic malignancy of any kind
- Unable to give informed consent.
